ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: nice introduction to American literature, made me better at reading critically and writing

I learned how to be a better reader and writer. One of the most important skills that I learned was how to perform close readings of texts to thoroughly understand underlying themes and symbols. Also, researching the meaning behind words is very important to understand the passage!

I learned more about American authors such as Dickinson and Walt Whitman. I learned the importance of looking up words or references I don't understand, because they can provide a lot of insight into the work.

Throughout this course, we learned how to analyze literature effectively and get the most out of the reading process. We also were able to compare different media that creators use to distribute their work and the impacts that choice of medium has on the audience.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Williams is definitely the strength - classes were enjoyable and laid-back, and I never felt nervous about participating

I honestly loved the course so much. The structure of the course was fantastic - I liked how Professor Williams walked through analyzing passages with us. I definitely learned a lot about how to approach difficult passages and how to appreciate the meaning of specific words.
The class allowed us to read and think about many different pieces of literature in new ways. However, there was a lack of consistency in depth across all the texts.

Strengths - Prof does a good job of opening the students eyes to deeper meanings in the text, by pulling a part a single passage and showing us all the different ways we can interpret it.
Weakness- he didn't ask the most insightful questions to prompt our discussion. Additionally, I wish he had cold called us at the beginning so that we could have learned the importance of participating in class much earlier on. 
Finally, there was no feedback on my writing, meaning literally no growth in my writing skills.

The choice of literary works we examined in the class was very strong, which helped give us an idea of the progression of American literature over the course of history. In-class discussions were engaging and interesting, and contributed greatly to our understanding of the literature.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the seminar-styled virtual course worked relatively well. Of course the class would have been better if it was in person, but I think that Professor Williams did an amazing job making sure that the discussions were engaging and that we were learning a lot.

I think Professor Williams did a good job of creating intellectual stimulating power points that helped us understand the works we read and opened our eyes to deeper meanings, even as we were on zoom.
I thought the organization of the class worked well, with the students reading independently and then coming to class to discuss what we had read.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're at all interested in literature or even just need a writing credit

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If I'm to be completely honest, literature is not my favorite subject, but ENGL 127 was super amazing with Professor Williams and was my favorite class this semester!
It was a good intro but kind of simple
I would but I would recommend looking into what section you choose since each teaching style is different.

Yes but NOT this professor. Prof Williams did a good job of delving into the American authors on the syllabus that he knew well, but did little to prepare teaching new authors, and gave absolutely NO feedback on my writing.

Yes! I would definitely recommend this course to other students - the readings were interesting, class discussions were engaging, and the class as a whole helped develop our analysis of literary works and increase our understanding of the history and current state of American literature.
